title-group.article-title: Development of a stratified tank storage component for ESP-r with embedded phase change material modules

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue on micro-generation and related energy technologies and practices for low carbon buildings

abstract.p: Solar domestic hot water systems are very common and are considered an efficient system for exploiting the renewable energy source of the sun, for instance national Italian regulations require the adoption of solar domestic hot water systems in new buildings. Water tanks are typical components for such systems, but have a serious drawback since they require a great amount of space in buildings. In this article, a new water tank model with embedded phase change material modules for the ESP-r code is presented in order to assess the possibility of using reduced size water tanks with additional latent storage. This article describes the numerical model used to deal with phase change phenomena and the incorporation of the method into ESP-r source code. To validate the model, the results of a test case have been compared with the literature data. A typical solar domestic hot water system has been simulated in order to study the impact of the phase change material modules inside tanks on the energy performance of the system. The results are reported using a global parameter that represents the fractional primary energy saved using the solar system. Water temperature plots with and without phase change material have been reported as well.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The constant increase of energy consumption due to building climatization is a major concern for industrialized countries, in Europe it absorbs over 30% of the total energy requirement. Energy saving strategies must be implemented in order to stop the actual trend. European Union has developed an ambitious plan for reducing building energy use, implementing policies that can improve the building’s fabric and increase the use of renewable energy sources. In this framework, it is important to develop efficient systems that use different energy sources like solar thermal, photovoltaic and geothermal.

The integration of different systems requires the balance between energy sources, building loads and demands. This is usually achieved by water storage tanks used as energy buffer, capable of accumulating energy when available and releasing it when required.

A typical solar domestic hot water (SDHW) system incorporates a proper sized tank to accumulate hot water. Sometimes, this can represent a problem since the tank usually occupies a substantial amount of space requiring dedicated rooms. A possible solution to the problem is to enhance the energy accumulation capabilities by integrating the sensible heat storage of water with a latent heat storage reservoir using phase change materials (PCMs).

Various works are available in the literature dealing with PCM enhanced tanks, Esen et al.1 consider two type of PCM units, the first made of packed cylinders with a fluid flowing parallel to it and the second a vessel filled with PCM with heat transfer fluid flowing in cylindrical pipes. They solved the change phase problem using numerical analysis and found that geometry and PCM should be considered together for optimizing the system. Cabeza et al.2 carried a series of experiments with a water tank including PCM modules, they obtained time histories of the temperature inside the tank at different heights along with the temperature of the PCM modules, they concluded that the inclusion of PCM modules in water tank is a promising technology for hot water supply.

Ibañez et al.3 developed the Type 60PCM model for TRNSYS by modifying the original type 60 component. The PCM store is not numerically modelled but instead an experimental enthalpy–temperature curve has to be entered by the user. They obtained very good concordance with the experimental data obtained by Cabeza et al.2 Castell et al.4 analysed the effect of finned surfaces at the external side of cylindrical modules filled with the same PCM–graphite compound used in Cabeza et al.2 and Ibañez et al.3 Bony and Citherlet5 developed a new component for TRNSYS using again the Type 60 component, they numerically solved the phase change problem inside PCM modules with an explicit two-dimensional finite volume discretisation, and also considered different module shapes. The developed model considered also hysteresis and subcooling effects, but using paraffin they declared the effects were negligible.

In a previous work,6 the authors modified the ESP-r simulation code by inserting PCM modules inside a perfectly mixed tank. The modification of the code consisted also in the inclusion of two heat exchangers in order to simulate SDHW plant systems. The major drawback of the model consisted in the lack of stratification inside the tank.

In this article, a new plant component has been added to the simulation code ESP-r, the PCM modules have been added by modifying a tank component that features water stratification and one or two internal heat exchangers. The model will be used to assess the performance of water tanks of reduced size for SDHW systems in different climatic conditions.

sec.title: Simulation models
sec.p: The new tank model is a modification of the already available stratified tank with submerged heat exchangers, introduced as component number 104 in ESP-r version 11.10. In this code, plant components are modelled with a finite volume discretization, each component is subdivided in nodes, and balance equations are written for each node. The tank component is a two or three node model, were one node represents the water and the metal casing while the others represent one or two immersed heat exchangers.

sec.title: Tank model
sec.p:
The tank model implemented in ESP-r considers a vertical subdivision with up to 100 layers for taking into account water stratification as reported in Figure 1(a), for each tank layer a conservation equation is written which take into account the heat conduction with the up and lower layers, the surrounding ambient air, the contribution of the immersed coils and of the water flow inside the tank. After the solution of the temperature distribution, an additional loop for water stratification is carried which assures that the temperature in each layer is higher than the one of the lower layer.7 The tank model is directly accessible since ESP-r is an open source code, the model is described in files stratified_tank.F, stratified_tank_1HX.F and stratified_tank_2HX.F for one and two internal heat exchangers, respectively. In this study, the balance equations for each tank layer have been modified to include the contribution of the PCM module. Figure 1.
Stratified tank with PCM modules and heat exchanger (a) tank layer subdivision and b) PCM module discretization in axial direction.

sec.title: PCM modules
sec.p: Some assumptions have been taken to implement the phase change phenomena inside the modules. The PCM modules are considered to be cylindrical containers packed in vertical direction as shown in Figure 1(a), as an enhancement from the method applied in Padovan and Manzan,6 the axial conduction has been modelled while the thickness of the cylinder wall is neglected. The modules are immersed in the water and the heat transfer occurs by mixed convection. The number, the dimension of cylindrical containers and PCM properties are inputs entered in ESP-r by the user, using the standard menu driven front end of network plant model definition.

sec.title: Solution of the enthalpy equation
sec.p: Phase change problems can be dealt with using different strategies. The change of state of a material implies a moving boundary and a different set of equations for the liquid, the solid zones and interface, this is referred as a Stefan problem. To avoid the difficulties of tracking the interface an enthalpy formulation has been adopted as suggested by Voller.8 In this formulation, the energy equations for liquid and solid phases are replaced by the following single equation (1)ρ∂h∂t=∇·(k∇θ) (2)h={csθ;θ<θpcclθ+(cs-cl)θpc+L;θ≥θpc

This formulation is valid for both liquid and solid phases and includes the Stefan heat balance condition at the interface. Equations (1) and (2) can be solved using an explicit or an implicit formulation, in the former case the computational burden is reduced per time step but a stability limit must be satisfied.

In this article, an explicit formulation has been used to solve equation (1), therefore, the time step is accordingly short to avoid stability problems. In Padovan and Manzan,6 an implicit method was used for solving the one-dimensional discretization of equation (1) and the extension to the two-dimensional case presented here is straightforward. However the stratified tank model used in ESP-r uses an explicit method for dealing with heat exchangers inside the tank requiring a sub-stepping technique.7 The combination of short simulation time steps for the tank heat exchanger solution and the computational cost at each time step required to solve the linear system arising from the implicit version of equation (1) lead to higher computational time, therefore, the simpler and faster explicit formulation has been selected.
Temperature and enthalpy relation can be written as (3)θP={hPcshP<cSθpcθpccsθpc≤hP<csθpc+LhP-(cs-cl)θpc-LclhP≥csθpc+L
Equation (1) can be discretized over a finite volume grid obtaining the general finite volume form (4)ρaP0hPn=ρaP0hP0+∑anbθnb0-aPθP0
For stability, the time and space steps need to be chosen such that (5)max|ΔθksρcsΔr2,ΔθklρclΔr2,ΔθksρcsΔy2,ΔθklρclΔy2|≤14

Equation (4) can be solved at each time step obtaining the nodal enthalpy field, the computation is completed by obtaining the temperature nodal field using equation (3). In Voller,8 a method for extracting liquid fraction distributions is also presented, but it has not been implemented, since only the heat flux coupling between PCM module and tank is required for the balance equation for each water tank layer solution.

sec.title: PCM module discretization
sec.p:
The cylindrical PCM modules have been discretized using a finite volume approach obtaining the coefficients of equation (4). The packing of the PCM is cylindrical and the axial conduction has also been considered, therefore, a two-dimensional axisymmetric formulation has been employed. In axial direction, the finite volumes match the layer subdivision of the tank, as shown in Figure 1(b), while in radial direction the generic finite control volume is a ring with inner radius (RE + RP)/2 and outer radius (RW + RP)/2 as shown in Figure 2(a). It is worth noting that the discretization in axial direction can lead to a non-uniform grid subdivision depending on the position of the PCM modules inside the tank, as shown in Figure 1(b). Figure 2.
Cell discretization for (a) top view and (b) lateral view.

The temperature field of the PCM is computed using, as boundary condition, the temperatures of the corresponding layers obtained at previous time step, the heat transfer coefficients are obtained using a mixed convection formulation that takes into account the temperature difference between the PCM module surface and water and the possible mass flow between inlet and outlet of the water tank crossing a discretized layer.

To compute the natural convection contribution the temperature difference between tank and modules is obtained using the average values of water and surface module temperatures of the layers corresponding to the PCM module.

By integration of equation (1) on the generic finite volume represented in Figure 2, the following balance equation can be written for each internal cell (6)ρVPΔthPn+1=ρVPΔthPn+kEAEΔRPEθEn+kWAWΔRPWθWn +kNANΔlPNθNn+kSASΔlPSθSn -(kEAEΔRPE+kWAWΔRPW+kNANΔlPN+kSASΔlPS)θPn where AE = 2(RE + RP)/2π lj is the east surface of the volume, while AW = 2(RW + RP)/2πlj the west surface area and lj the height of the corresponding layer.

Different equations will be obtained for the element on the cylinder axis and for the element situated at the boundary. In the former case, the contribution of the east node is neglected, while for the latter the west contribution is replaced with a convective coupling term with the corresponding fluid tank water layer, as shown in Figure 2(b) (7)ρVPΔthPn+1=ρVPΔthPn+kEAEΔRPEθEn+kNANΔlPNθNn+kSASΔlPSθSn -(kEAEΔRPE+kNANΔlPN+kSASΔlPS)θPn+qC where (8)qC=αnAC(θtank-θPn)

Equation (8) represents the boundary condition for the problem since θtank is known from the previous time step, while αnis computed using a mixed convection correlation using previous time step temperature values.
Equation (6), with boundary condition (7) is solved at each time step and the flux obtained with equation (8) is inserted in the balance equation for determining the temperature of each tank layer.

The described model does not take into account convective terms in liquid and mushy regions since the filling material for the modules is a PCM–graphite compound. In this particular case, the conductivity is mainly dictated by the solid structure of the graphite composite, as reported by Castell et al.4

The extension of the applied method to the general case of PCM without a solid matrix is not straightforward due to the presence of convective effects in liquid and mushy regions. In literature, different approaches have been envisioned to deal with this phenomena. The straightforward solution is to solve the complete set of Navier–Stokes and Energy equations to obtain velocities and temperature distributions on the liquid and mushy regions, this approach has been followed by Voller and Prakash;9 however, the high computational time and the fine grids required for PCM discretization hinders the possibility to use this approach efficiently on a building and plant simulating code. An alternative simplified approach, as proposed by Laouadi and Lacroix10 and Ait Adine and El Qarnia,11 is to use natural convection correlations to increase the conductivity of the liquid region. This method appears sound and easy to be implemented, unfortunately it has been applied in one-dimensional phase change problems only. Preliminary simulations of the current PCM module geometry using the approach of Voller and Prakash,9 showed strong two-dimensional temperature and velocities distributions, not obtainable with the simplified methods of Laouadi and Lacroix10 and Ait Adine and El Qarnia.11

The applicability of the presented ESP-r tank plant component is limited to the cases in which convective effects in the PCM can be neglected, on the other hand, as in the case presented here, the use of a PCM graphite compounds is beneficial because of the higher thermal conductivity of the PCM.

sec.title: Modification of ESP-r routines
sec.p: The procedure has been implemented into a routine called by the ESP-r plant component coefficient generator. First two new plant components have been added to the plant database file. These two components represent tanks with PCM modules, the former with one heat exchanger, the latter with two immersed heat exchangers.

Some additional input data are required for the new tank model in order to describe the PCM material and module geometry. Table 1 presents the additional inputs introduced in order to describe the PCM modules. The first parameter represents the number of modules, if it is set to zero, no PCM module is considered and the standard stratification water tank model is used by the code. The following eight inputs are the PCM thermophysical parameters. The ‘phase change temperature’ parameter is the temperature at which phase change occurs and correspond to θpc. Then, the size of the module is defined, while the next parameter indicates the position from the bottom of the tank of the lower surface of the module, this is an important value since it determines which layer of the tank is affected by the PCM module. The last parameter is the numerical grid subdivision in radial direction, in axial direction no number of subdivisions is required since it is computed automatically from the number of layers chosen for the water tank. The added routine computes the coefficients and solves equation (4). Due to the limitations in time step for the stability of the explicit scheme, equation (5) is used to determine the time step required, therefore, at each plant system time step used by ESP-r, a number of internal time steps are computed by the PCM routine. The routine at the end of execution returns the exchanged flux using equation (8) which is added to the known term of the tank node layer computation.

sec.title: Test and example
sec.p: The new component has been first tested using experimental data available in the literature. Ibanez et al.3 carried a series of tests for validating a similar component developed for the TRNSYS code. One test was the cooling down of a tank filled with water with homogeneous and high initial temperature. In the process, the water cools triggering the phase change of PCM modules. The cylindrical tank has a volume of 147 L; it is 125 cm high with a diameter of 39 cm and has been simulated with 20 water layers. The PCM modules are two cylindrical bottles with 8.8 cm diameter and 31.5 cm height. Since the bottles are filled with 1.5 L of PCM, a height of 24.7 cm has been considered for the simulation; the modules are placed at 0.75 m from the bottom of the tank and they are discretized with 20 radial cells. The filling material for the modules is a PCM–graphite composite and following Cabeza et al.,2 the data used are density of 1.4 kg/L a melting point of 56 °C, heat capacity of 2.5 kJ/(kg K) and thermal conductivity of 2 W/(m K).

Experimental results show stratification of water inside the tank. In a previous work,6 a similar component for the ESP-r code could not deal with stratification; with the present component, on the other hand, the stratification is well identifiable as is the effect of PCM modules, the timings for the beginning of the solidification phase of the PCM and the temperature at the end of the cooling down process correspond well with the ones reported by Ibanez et al.3

Figure 3 shows the time development of water temperature in four layers. It is worth noting that the experiment showed a strong stratification of hot water in the upper part of the tank where the PCM modules were installed, the same behaviour is detected in Figure 3 where it can be detected the low temperature values reached quite quickly by the water layers at the bottom of the tank and higher temperatures in the upper part, it is worth noting that layer 19 is directly affected by the presence of the PCM modules since it spans from 112.5 to 118.75 cm from the bottom of the tank. Figure 3.
Comparison of layer temperatures in cooling down experiment.

sec.title: Example of SDHW use
sec.p:
To test the effect of PCM modules into a water tank for SDHW, an ESP-r plant model has been developed. Figure 4 represents the simulated plant; it features a water tank with two immersed heat exchanges, a boiler and a solar panel. With strong solar loads, water temperature can reach high values in the tank, therefore, to provide DHW with a temperature of about 40 °C, a three-way valve has been added to the plant which deviates water from the makeup water in order to control the supply water temperature. The solar collector pump is activated only when the temperature in the collector is higher than the one at the mid-height of the tank, while the boiler pump is activated when the temperature of the layer where the tank output is situated falls below 45 °C and it is deactivated when the temperature rises over 50 °C. Figure 4.
Simulated SDHW plant system.
DHW: domestic hot water.

All plant components, apart from the tank and the three-way valve, are already present in ESP-r database, the boiler is component number 17, a gas fired boiler which provides water at a constant temperature of 60 °C, the solar collector is component number 84 with a total area of 4.72 m2, while daily DHW hourly draw profile is obtained using component n° 88. Makeup water is provided to the plant at a constant temperature of 15 °C.

To assess the performance of the PCM-enhanced water tanks, a number of simulations have been carried in two sites with different climate conditions: Trieste and Rome. The former, located in the north east part of Italy is characterized by a diffuse horizontal solar radiation of 632.15 kWh, direct horizontal of 423.29 kWh direct normal 673.67 kWh, while the latter is in centre Italy with diffuse horizontal solar radiation of 705.58 kWh, direct horizontal of 741.93 kWh direct normal 1204.27 kWh with higher temperatures throughout the year.

Following Heimrat and Haller,12 the fractional thermal energy savings parameter has been computed which represents a measure of the percentage of non-solar energy input for heating that can be reduced by the solar system. (9)fsav,therm=1-QpriQpri,ref at the denominator of equation (9) appears the primary energy consumption without solar system, while the numerator represents the primary energy consumption with the solar system.

The PCM material used for the example is the same PCM–graphite composite used for the test case. Two water tanks with volumes of 147 and 73 L, respectively, are employed. The former is identical to the one used for the test case, while the latter represents a reduced size water tank with an height of 0.8 m with a diameter of 0.35 m. The modules in this case have been placed at 0.55 m from the bottom of the tank. In both cases eight PCM modules, corresponding to a total volume of 12 L have been considered. The tank in this case has been discretized with eight layers, while the PCM modules use 20 radial cells. The tank volumes are undersized with respect to the ones normally used for SDHW system, but they have been selected to test the ability of the modelled PCM modules to reduce the amount of building space employed by such systems.

One of the key parameters when dealing with PCMs is the phase change temperature, since it triggers the latent heat storage, therefore, this parameter has to be carefully selected for each application. To highlight this phenomena, the simulations have been performed considering two change phase temperatures 55 °C and 60 °C. The former corresponds to the one used in Padovan and Manzan6 using a tank model without stratification. Table 2 reports the fractional energy saving term computed for the different sites and temperatures. The results show that the insertion of PCM modules only marginally improves the performance of the water system. Nevertheless from an analysis of the two tables, it is clear that the system when operated in a warmer climate yields better results than the one installed in the cooler one. For Rome, the fractional thermal energy saving is significantly higher, due to the favourable climatic conditions. The larger benefit can be identified for the high volume tank in warmer climate. The phase change temperature somewhat alters the results, a plot of exit temperatures of the tank for a week in October in Rome is shown in Figures 5 and 6. Figure 5.

From the inspection of Figures 5 and 6 it results that the lower volume tank is characterized by an higher temperature difference, furthermore phase change phenomena affects only marginally the higher volume tank, as the water temperature does not fall below 55 °C and for the most part of the time the temperature is substantially higher than the phase change temperature.

A similar pattern is observed in Figures 7 and 8 where the temperature plots are shown for the two different size tanks containing a PCM with a phase change temperature of 60 °C. Figure 7.

The effect of latent heat is clearly identified especially for the 73 L tank where the maximum exit temperature is substantially lower and the temperature of the layer is preserved for a larger time. The same trend for the 147 L tank is observed, but showing less evidence.

The obtained results refer to a case with only 12 L of PCM which lead to a fraction of less than 9% of the occupied volume for the larger tank and less than 20% for the other. These amounts have been computed considering the tank available space not occupied by heat exchangers, better results should be obtained with an increase of the amount of PCM, this could only be obtained with tanks especially designed. For the tanks considered here, the PCM modules have been positioned on top of the heat exchangers, while alternate solution could consider the PCM modules positioned inside the helical heat exchangers. This suggests that an optimization should be performed in order to obtain the cost effectiveness of the PCM enhanced tanks which considers both the available space, phase change temperature and geometry of the modules.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p:
The results can be influenced by the discretization of both tank and PCM modules. To assess the impact of the vertical discretization of the water tank and radial discretization of PCM modules, a sensitivity analysis has been performed using the climatic data of Rome. For the discretization of the tank 20 and 40 layers have been employed, while for the module 20 and 40 cells in radial direction have been tested. Table 3 reports the fractional thermal energy saving of equation (9). Three new cases have been identified by composing tank subdivisions and radial module discretization. The cases are named using the first number as the tank discretization, while the second for module radial discretization. Table 3.

It can be clearly detected the strong influence of the number of layers in tank discretization while the refinement in radial PCM discretization has a lower impact affecting only the results for the lower volume tank. The major observation is that the increase in tank discretization leads to a general decrease of fractional energy saving term, but this affect in equal manner the cases with or without PCM modules, this indicates that this parameter does not interfere directly with the PCM model, but that has a strong relevance for the modelling of the tank. However, also the refinement of the tank model leads to an increase of the computational time, the simulations with 20 layers increase the computational time by a factor 1.6 respect the basic eight layer case, while the 40 layers case lead to an increase factor up to 2.4, therefore, a trade-off has to be carried between computational cost and results correctness.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A tank plant component in ESP-r database has been enhanced by the addition of immersed PCM modules. The enthalpy model implemented to deal with phase change problems has been illustrated. The new component requires some additional variables to describe the thermophysical properties of the PCM, but can be used in the same plant schemes as the component it derives from.

To test the performance of the component, a comparison with experimental published literature results has been carried with good results. An SDHW system has been simulated to verify the impact of PCM on energy storage in undersized water tanks, the results show that the improvements are not dramatic so the effective utilization of the PCM modules in low volume tanks requires further research. Additional work is required for tuning the parameters of the model in order to optimize the system, with particular reference to the change phase temperature and position of PCM modules inside the tank. An effort for designing tanks with much space for accommodating additional PCM modules is required, usually the inner volume of existing tanks is already occupied by heat exchangers, therefore, the water tanks for PCM inclusion should be designed from the beginning with the problem of PCM allocation in mind, also geometries others than the cylindrical one could be tested. The proposed method could be easily arranged to deal with different geometries.
